636
We have another piece of evidence for iaovojuia,  roughly belonging to the same period as the Harmodius song,  i.  e.  c,  500 B.  C. ,  which may also claim aristocratic origin.  The Pythagorean physician Alcmaeon^® used the contrast between isonomia and monarchy to define illness and health,  the latter being an laovofiia of powers,  and illness the result of fiovaqxid or the predominence of one power.  It is obvious that Alcmaeon borrowed his ideas from the political field ; the conclusion took the opposite way to the more usual one : the body natural is seen in the image of the body political.  The physical laovofxia is supposed to be a state of balance,  an » equalitarian harmony« among the forces working in the human body,  an equality as it were in physical citizenship^^.  The Pythagoreans in general had cratic sympathies,  and if there was any particular tendency in Alcmaeon's use of the political imagery,  the »good distribution« of evvojuia would probably have been more suitable^®.  But Alcmaeon followed his model even more closely.  The decisive point was again the contrast to the rule of one single power,  to monarchy.  Solon's evvofiia had followed a state of oligarchic preponderance and misrule,  while iaovo / biia was and remained the answer to a tyrant's rule. 
The political revolution which began with the expulsion of Hippias and culminated in Cleisthenes' great reform of the political order,  started under the watchword iaovofxiay but soon became the rule of the people.  It is,  however,  a mistake ( in which I too have shared ) to assume that uyovofila^ after an initial aristocratic phase,  simply preceded ôrjfiOKQarta as a name for the same thing.  The very nature of each of the two expressions suggests that they did not mean the same.  They were almost contemporary ; but democracy was a form of government,  a constitution,  while » isonomia ( like eunomid ) was not a constitution,  nor a state of equal law for everybody ; it was the ideal of a community in wliich the citizens had their equal share It is understandable that Herodotus,  who had no discriminating knowledge

48.  That is why Larsen ( p.  9 ) can say that Alcmaeon's model was ^a balanced State *,  an ideal that »would be natural enough for those who favoured a Solonian type of government«.  G.  Thomson,  Aeschylus and Athens,  2ioff. ,  asserts that the Pythagoreans were democrats.  He lays stress on the »doctrine of the mean«,  but that is Solonian rather than democratic,  and laovofila,  as I try to explain,  is not simply a »democratic watchword«.  The Pythagoreans with their mixture of mathematics and mystics were probably not strictly bound to any political form ; in our context it is only important that Alcmaeon saw iaovofiia purely as a contrast to monarchy.
